meanings.def: to defeat somebody in a game or competition
examples: beat somebody at something He beat me at chess.
beat somebody She was narrowly beaten by the German in the final.
I beat her by just three points.
Their recent wins have proved they're still the ones to beat (= the most difficult team to beat).
He was beaten into second place by the American.
He was narrowly beaten by his opponent.
Watson was a higher-rated player who consistently beat her.
Her entry really did beat the others hands down.
She won the 100 metres, beating a number of top Europeans.
They were soundly beaten in the finals by a much stronger Dutch side.

meanings.def: to do or be better than something
examples: Nothing beats home cooking.
You can't beat Italian shoes.
For a break in the sun, Thailand is hard to beat.
They want to beat the speed record (= go faster than anyone before).
This is his latest attempt to beat the world record.

meanings.def: to get control of something
examples: The government's main aim is to beat inflation.
Book a break in the sun to try to beat those winter blues.
He is struggling to beat his addiction.
The new law is a way of trying to beat terrorism.

meanings.def: to be too difficult for somebody
examples: beat somebody It is a problem that beats even the experts.
beat somebody why, how, etc… It beats me (= I don't know) why he did it.
What beats me (= what I don't understand) is how it was done so quickly.
‘Where's she gone?’ ‘Beats me.’

meanings.def: to avoid something
examples: If we go early we should beat the traffic.
We were up and off early to beat the heat.

meanings.def: to hit a person hard and many times in order to hurt them
examples: beat somebody At that time children were regularly beaten for quite minor offences (= as a punishment).
beat somebody + adv./prep. A man was found beaten to death.
The prisoners were beaten into submission (= they were beaten until they did what was wanted).
beat somebody + adj. They beat him unconscious (= hit him until he became unconscious).
The men took him out into the street and beat him senseless.

meanings.def: to hit something hard several times
examples: + adv./prep. Somebody was beating at the door.
Hailstones beat against the window.
beat something Someone was beating a drum.
beat something + adv./prep. I was beating dust out of the rugs (= removing dust from the rugs by beating them).
Someone was beating at the door.
A young man was found beaten to death last night.
At that time, children were often beaten for quite minor offences (= as a punishment).
He had been badly battered around the head and face.
Severe winds have been battering the coast.
Heavy rain pounded on the roof.
The rain lashed at the window.
He hammered the door with his fists.
They could hear the rain beating on the roof.
He was beating the carpet with a large brush.
His stepfather repeatedly beat his mother.
He had been beaten around the head with a rock.
She was beaten with a metal bar.
They used to get beaten with a wooden spoon.

meanings.def: to make, or cause something to make, a regular sound or movement
examples: She's alive—her heart is still beating.
His heart started beating faster.
We heard the drums beating.
The bird was beating its wings (= moving them up and down) frantically.
Her heart began to beat a little faster.
I could feel my heart beating wildly.
I could detect a pulse beating very faintly.
Its wings beat feebly against the window.
The bird was frantically beating its wings.

meanings.def: to mix something with short quick movements with a fork, etc.
examples: beat something up Beat the eggs up to a frothy consistency.
beat something Beat the mixture well, until it is light and creamy.
Add three eggs, lightly beaten.
beat A and B together Beat the flour and milk together.

meanings.def: to change the shape of something, especially metal, by hitting it with a hammer, etc.
examples: beat something (out) (into something) The gold is beaten out into thin strips.
beaten silver
beat something + adj. The metal had been beaten flat.

meanings.def: to make a path, etc. by walking somewhere or by pressing branches down and walking over them
examples: a well-beaten track (= one that has been worn hard by much use)
The hunters beat a path through the undergrowth.

meanings.def: to talk about something for a long time without coming to the main point
examples: Stop beating about the bush and tell me what you want.

meanings.def: to defeat or do better than somebody in an activity which they have chosen or in which they think they are strong
to think very hard about something for a long time
examples: I’ve been beating my brains out all weekend to get this script written.

meanings.def: to show that you feel sorry about something that you have done, especially in public and in an exaggerated way
to finish a task, race, etc. before a particular time
examples: The player beat the clock and set a new record.

meanings.def: to hit somebody very hard several times and hurt them very much
examples: Get out or I’ll beat the living daylights out of you!

meanings.def: to waste your effort by trying to do something that is no longer possible
to speak with enthusiasm in support of somebody/something
examples: She’s really banging the drum for the new system.

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something very hard
examples: He was a dirty player and loved to kick hell out of the opposition.

meanings.def: to go away immediately
examples: This is private land, so beat it!

meanings.def: if a lot of people beat a path to somebody’s door, they are all interested in something that person has to sell, or can do or tell them
examples: Top theatrical agents are beating a path to the teenager's door.

meanings.def: to escape without being punished
to go away or back quickly, especially to avoid something unpleasant
examples: I decided to beat a hasty retreat.

meanings.def: to mark or follow the rhythm of music, by waving a stick, tapping your foot (= hitting it against the floor), etc.
examples: She beat time with her fingers.

meanings.def: to get or do something before somebody else can
(to hit somebody until they are) covered with bruises (= blue, brown or purple marks on the body)
used to express surprise or anger
if you cannot defeat somebody or be as successful as they are, then it is more sensible to join them in what they are doing and perhaps get some advantage for yourself by doing so
far away from other people, houses, etc.
examples: They live miles off the beaten track.

meanings.def: a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to be difficult to beat
examples: That score is going to take some beating.
For sheer luxury, this hotel takes some beating.

idioms.def: to talk about something for a long time without coming to the main point
examples: Stop beating about the bush and tell me what you want.

meanings.def: a single hit to something, such as a drum, or a movement of something, such as your heart; the sound that this makes
examples: several loud beats on the drum
a heart rate of 80 beats per minute

meanings.def: a series of regular hits to something, such as a drum; the sound that this makes
examples: the steady beat of the drums
She felt the beat of his heart.

meanings.def: the main rhythm, or a unit of rhythm, in a piece of music, a poem, etc.
examples: This type of music has a strong beat to it.
The piece has four beats to the bar.
Pause for two beats and then repeat the chorus.
The track opens with a pounding drum beat.
to the beat She tapped her fingers to the beat of the music.
Count four beats and then start singing.
He chants his lyrics over an infectious disco beat.
They danced to the rhythmic beat of the music.

meanings.def: the area that a police officer walks around regularly and which they are responsible for
examples: on the beat More police officers out on the beat may help to cut crime.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has a sudden feeling of fear, excitement, etc.
examples: My heart missed a beat when I saw who it was.

meanings.def: to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas
examples: She was a gifted and original artist who marched to a different drummer.

meanings.def: to walk around the area that they are responsible for
examples: We have two officers walking the beat after midnight.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody has a sudden feeling of fear, excitement, etc.
examples: My heart missed a beat when I saw who it was.
